title: Creating My Academic Website with Quarto
text:
As a graduate student in Biochemistry, Microbiology, and Molecular Biology at Penn State, I needed a professional website to showcase my CV and share updates about my research. I initially started with a simple Jekyll-based GitHub Pages site, but I wanted something more flexible and powerful.
Enter Quarto - an open-source scientific and technical publishing system that‚Äôs perfect for academics. Here‚Äôs why I made the switch:



Computational Integration: Quarto can embed R, Python, and Julia code, which is perfect for sharing research analyses and visualizations in future blog posts.
Superior PDF Export: I can easily export my CV to PDF with consistent formatting - essential for job applications and conference submissions.
Modern Tooling: Quarto is actively developed by Posit (formerly RStudio) and has excellent documentation and community support.
Unified Publishing: One system for websites, presentations, papers, and books. As I progress through my PhD, I can use Quarto for dissertation chapters, posters, and more.

title: Creating My Academic Website with Quarto
text:
The Conversion Process

From Jekyll to Quarto
The conversion was surprisingly straightforward:

Configuration: I replaced _config.yml with _quarto.yml, which defines the site structure, navigation, and theme.
Content: My CV (index.md) became index.qmd with just a YAML header addition. All the Markdown content stayed identical - Quarto is fully compatible with standard Markdown.
Theme: I chose the cosmo theme for its clean, professional appearance. It‚Äôs similar to Jekyll‚Äôs minimal theme but more customizable.
Blog Setup: I created a blog.qmd listing page that automatically aggregates posts from the posts/ directory, sorted chronologically.



GitHub Actions Deployment
The biggest change was setting up automated deployment via GitHub Actions. Jekyll builds automatically on GitHub Pages, but Quarto requires a workflow file:
# .github/workflows/publish.yml
name: Publish Quarto Website

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  build-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: write
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: quarto-dev/quarto-actions/setup@v2

      - name: Render and Publish
        uses: quarto-dev/quarto-actions/publish@v2
        with:
          target: gh-pages
        env:
          GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
This workflow: - Triggers on every push to the main branch - Installs Quarto - Renders the site - Deploys to the gh-pages branch


Repository Configuration
Two critical GitHub settings were required:

Actions Permissions: Settings ‚Üí Actions ‚Üí General ‚Üí Set ‚ÄúRead and write permissions‚Äù
Pages Source: Settings ‚Üí Pages ‚Üí Deploy from branch: gh-pages / root

title: Creating My Academic Website with Quarto
text:
What I Learned

Challenges
GitHub Actions Permissions: Initially, my workflow failed because GitHub Actions didn‚Äôt have write permissions. The fix was simple but not immediately obvious.
Branch Deployment: I chose the gh-pages branch approach over the docs/ folder method. It keeps the main branch cleaner and follows standard conventions.


Benefits
Markdown Compatibility: All my existing content worked perfectly - no reformatting needed.
Extensibility: I can now easily add computational content, interactive visualizations, and more sophisticated layouts as my needs grow.
Professional Appearance: The site looks polished and modern, which is important for making a good impression on potential collaborators and employers.
